questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of a rash on his scalp and forehead. The parents report that the rash has been present for several weeks. They state that the rash is sometimes red and scaly, especially when it is cold. The patient was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has generally been healthy since. His father has psoriasis. The patient appears comfortable. Examination shows several erythematous patches on the scalp, forehead, and along the hairline. Some patches are covered by greasy yellow scales. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonbullous impetigo can manifest in infants with erythema and honey-colored crusting involving the face. However, the crusts are typically dried secretions that arise from ruptured pustules or vesicles, rather than scales. Furthermore, it primarily affects children aged between 2 and 6 years. Although the face is commonly involved, a rash around the nose and mouth would be more common than lesions on the scalp and along the hairline. In addition, warm and humid climates, rather than cold temperatures, are risk factors for this condition.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

B) INCORRECT:

In infants, atopic dermatitis can manifest with a scaly rash involving the scalp and face. However, lesions are typically dry rather than greasy and are intensely pruritic. Moreover, disease flares in atopic dermatitis are triggered by heat and extremely dry or humid climates rather than cold temperatures.
Image Description:

Nodules and papular vesicles with crusting, scaling, and impetigo are seen on the head of an infant

C) INCORRECT:

Erythroderma may manifest with erythema and scaling as seen in this patient. It can be idiopathic or occur secondary to other dermatologic conditions. While the idiopathic type typically manifests in patients older than 40 years, the secondary type can occur earlier in life, depending on the underlying condition. However, erythroderma is characterized by generalized erythema rather than limited involvement of the face or scalp, and does not present with greasy scaling, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Erythema and thickening of the skin can be seen on the trunk and proximal lower limbs.

This is the typical appearance of erythroderma (exfoliative dermatitis), which may be idiopathic or occur secondary to a drug reaction or systemic diseases (e.g., psoriasis, atopic dermatitis).

D) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is characterized by the presence of greasy skin lesions that frequently involve the face, trunk, and back of the hands. However, this condition manifests with soft, sharply demarcated, pigmented papules or plaques that have a stuck-on appearance, rather than erythematous lesions with scaling. Seborrheic keratosis is also most common in the older population and would be unlikely to manifest in an infant.
Image Description:

Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)

Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis may manifest with an erythematous rash already during the neonatal period. The distribution pattern of the rash reflects the areas and shapes of external exposure (e.g., soaps or cosmetics used on the face and scalp). However, the contact dermatitis rash is usually papular, intensely pruritic, and may, in severe cases, form vesicles with serous oozing.
Image Description:

An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.

This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

F) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis rubra pilaris may manifest as a scaly rash. However, it typically involves the palms and soles rather than the scalp, and the associated rash is characterized by disseminated plaques with orange-pink scales and follicular keratosis. In addition, symptoms do not occur during infancy but usually begin during early childhood or adulthood.

G) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis may manifest with scaly, erythematous skin lesions that are typically located on the scalp, back, elbows, and knees (extensor surfaces). A positive family history increases the risk of developing the disease. However, psoriatic lesions have a classic silvery-white appearance and are usually well-demarcated, elevated, and mildly pruritic. Furthermore, the age of onset is usually between 20 and 40 years of age, making psoriasis less likely in this patient.
Image Description:

Silver-white scaling and plaques are visible on the scalp and forehead parallel to the hairline.

This is the characteristic appearance of psoriasis capitis.

H) CORRECT:

The infantile type of seborrheic dermatitis typically manifests within the first 3 months of life, most frequently in premature infants, with erythematous (or salmon-colored) scaling plaques and, in some cases, greasy, yellow, adherent scales that rarely cause mild pruritus. Typical locations include the scalp (hence the term “cradle cap”), forehead, nose, external ear, umbilical area, and intertriginous areas. The pathophysiology is not yet fully understood but colonization of areas around sebaceous glands with the yeast Malassezia furfur appears to be a contributing factor. In some patients (especially in adults) active phases are triggered by an inadequate or abnormal immune response to the yeast (e.g., due to stress, fatigue, or cold temperatures) leading to an inflammatory reaction of the skin. Seborrheic dermatitis is more common in patients with a family history of psoriasis.

The condition usually resolves spontaneously (within three to four months), but regular bathing, the use of baby shampoos, and the application of an emulsifying ointment can help relieve symptoms. Treatment with topical corticosteroids (low potency) and ketoconazole may be necessary in severe cases.
Image Description:

Photograph of the scalp of a 2-month-old

Yellow, scaling plaques on erythematous skin extend over the scalp.

This appearance in an infant is consistent with infantile seborrheic dermatitis.
questions.hint: This infant presents with a common inflammatory skin condition that affects areas with high sebaceous activity (e.g., the scalp) and usually resolves spontaneously.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a recurrent pruritic rash on his face and scalp. He reports that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. A year ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He drinks several six-packs of beer weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the rash is shown. A similar rash is seen near the hairline of the scalp and greasy yellow scales are seen at the margins of the eyelids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic lesions can manifest as pruritic erythematous scaly plaques that are recurrent with symptom-free intervals. However, the typical lesions will be sharply-demarcated with numerous silvery-white scales and have a predilection to occur on the scalp, back, and extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees. The characteristic silvery scales of a psoriatic lesion may be rubbed off while bathing or minimized with the use of lotions, making differentiating between psoriasis and this patient's condition difficult. It is helpful to consider nail changes, arthritis, and a family history of psoriasis if the lesions are indeterminate.
Image Description:

Multiple sharply demarcated erythematosquamous plaques with coarse, silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor sides of the lower arms and elbows.

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) can manifest with a pruritic, erythematous rash. However, this patient's rash is not limited to the parts of the skin he uses the shaving cream on; the scaly rash is also seen on his eyelids and forehead, and scales in ACD are dry and white rather than greasy and yellow. Moreover, ACD develops within 48 hours of contact with the allergen, and the 2-month period between this patient changing shaving cream and developing a rash is not consistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

The typical rash of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is symmetric erythema over the bridge of the nose and the cheeks that characteristically spares the nasolabial folds (butterfly rash). This patient's rash involves the nasolabial folds, is pruritic, and has greasy yellow scales, none of which are seen in SLE. In addition, other early manifestations of SLE, such as fatigue, myalgia, and arthritis, are absent in this patient, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

Cutaneous manifestations are uncommon in drug-induced lupus erythematosus but, when present, are different from the classic butterfly rash of SLE. The lesions may present as erythematous scaly papules that tend to coalesce. However, the antiretroviral drugs that this patient is taking are not known to trigger drug-induced lupus erythematosus.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash with adherent keratotic scaling is visible over the nasal bridge, cheek (malar eminence), brow, and chin. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold. Mild cheilitis is also visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. Because this rash typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically, resembling butterfly wings, it is also referred to as a "butterfly rash."

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic/recurrent central facial erythema (nose and medial cheeks) is a common feature of rosacea. In some patients, the eyelids are also involved (i.e., blepharitis in ocular rosacea). However, the lesions of rosacea are not pruritic and scales, if present, are dry and white, unlike in this patient. In addition, the most characteristic signs of rosacea, such as telangiectasia and/or papules and pustules in the affected area, are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.

E) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous manifestations of pellagra include bilaterally symmetrical erythematous lesions that usually affect sun-exposed areas (e.g., the face, neck), the hands, and the feet. A burning sensation is common in pellagra but pruritus is not expected. Although this patient's high consumption of alcohol is a risk factor for the development of pellagra, he has none of the other features of pellagra (i.e., diarrhea, glossitis, fatigue).
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

F) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis versicolor manifests with multiple, pruritic, well-demarcated lesions that may be mildly erythematous, hyperpigmented, or hypopigmented and are typically seen on the trunk and shoulders; the face is an uncommon site for pityriasis versicolor. The lesions have very fine white scales and do not tan, which is why they become more apparent after sun exposure.
Image Description:

Back of a patient

Multiple round, well-demarcated, confluent, depigmented macules are visible.

This finding indicates pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia species.

G) CORRECT:

Seborrheic dermatitis is an idiopathic, chronic, relapsing condition that manifests with a pruritic rash, affecting the face, eyelids, and/or scalp. Predisposing factors include immunodeficiency (e.g., HIV infection) and Parkinson disease. Malassezia furfur and Malassezia globosa are thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of seborrheic dermatitis, but the exact mechanism is unknown. Treatment consists of topical antifungals (e.g., ketoconazole) and topical steroids (for moderate to severe disease).

H) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis (DM) include midfacial erythema that affects the nasolabial folds and the eyelids (heliotrope rash), which is similar to the distribution of the rash seen in this patient. Although myopathy is an important and common symptom of DM, cutaneous features can precede the onset of myopathy. However, the skin manifestations of DM are non-pruritic, and other cutaneous manifestations like Gottron papules and the Shawl sign are missing, making DM an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.
Image Description:

Scaly, erythematous papules and periungual erythema are visible on the dorsal aspect of the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints.

Both localization and appearance are typical of Gottron papules, which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
questions.hint: This photograph shows well-defined erythematous plaques with fine, greasy yellow scales over the nasolabial folds. This condition can also affect infants and is known as cradle cap.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician with a 3-month history of an itchy rash on his face. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with early-onset Parkinson disease. His only medication is pramipexole. Physical examination shows the findings seen in the photograph. There is copious dandruff on his scalp without underlying erythema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's pruritic rash affecting areas of high sebaceous activity (i.e., face, eyelids, scalp) is typical of seborrheic dermatitis. While most cases are idiopathic, there is an increased prevalence of seborrheic dermatitis in patients with HIV infection, underlying neurological conditions (e.g. Parkinson disease, stroke), and intestinal malabsorption syndromes (e.g., celiac sprue). Malassezia furfur and Malassezia globosa are yeasts that are thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of seborrheic dermatitis, but the exact mechanism is unknown. Scalp lesions are typically treated with antifungal shampoos, and facial lesions are treated with low-dose topical steroids and/or antifungal creams.

B) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (eczema) can manifest with a pruritic, scaling rash involving the scalp and face, as is seen in this patient. However, atopic dermatitis typically manifests first in childhood, often with lesions on the face in infancy and lesions on the flexural surfaces of the body in childhood and adolescence. Moreover, it is commonly associated with other atopic diseases such as asthma and allergic rhinitis, neither of which this patient has.
Image Description:

Nodules and papular vesicles with crusting, scaling, and impetigo are seen on the head of an infant

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis (DM) is characterized by myopathy, which is commonly preceded by cutaneous features such as midfacial erythema that affects the nasolabial folds, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, cutaneous manifestations of DM are typically nonpruritic and involve the eyelids, unlike what is seen here. Moreover, DM is commonly associated with Gottron papules and the Shawl sign, neither of which is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Scaly, erythematous papules and periungual erythema are visible on the dorsal aspect of the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints.

Both localization and appearance are typical of Gottron papules, which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) typically manifests with symmetric erythema over the bridge of the nose and cheeks, and characteristically spares the nasolabial folds (butterfly rash). This patient's rash involves the nasolabial folds as well as the scalp and is more prominent around the beard. In addition, other early manifestations of SLE, such as constitutional (e.g., fatigue, myalgia, fever), mucocutaneous (e.g., oral ulcers), and musculoskeletal (e.g., arthritis, arthralgia) symptoms are absent.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash with adherent keratotic scaling is visible over the nasal bridge, cheek (malar eminence), brow, and chin. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold. Mild cheilitis is also visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. Because this rash typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically, resembling butterfly wings, it is also referred to as a "butterfly rash."

E) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) manifests with a pruritic, erythematous rash, as seen in this patient. However, ACD is caused by direct exposure to an irritant (e.g., nickel, latex, poison ivy), and this patient has no history of exposure.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Chronic/recurrent central facial erythema (nose and medial cheeks), as seen in this patient, is a common feature of rosacea. However, the lesions of rosacea are not pruritic, and the characteristic signs of rosacea, such as telangiectasia and/or papules and pustules in the affected area, are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.

G) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic lesions often first manifest between 20–40 years of age with pruritic, erythematous, scaly plaques, as seen in this patient. However, the lesions in psoriasis are sharply demarcated with numerous silver-white scales that characteristically manifest on the extensor surfaces of the body (e.g., elbows, knees, back); they typically do not occur on the face.
Image Description:

Multiple sharply demarcated erythematosquamous plaques with coarse, silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor sides of the lower arms and elbows.
questions.hint: This is a benign condition with a biphasic age of onset that most commonly manifests with scales on the scalp in infancy (cradle cap) or on the face in adolescence or early adulthood.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman reports itching and flaking of the face and scalp for the past several months. She has tried multiple dandruff shampoos and over-the-counter lotions without relief. She has no known medical diagnoses but has lost 4.5 kg unintentionally during the past 6 months.
Physical examination reveals yellowish scaling and erythema of her nasolabial creases and the skin around her eyebrows (figure). She also has greasy scaling of the scalp.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Stool examination for ova and parasites

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Greasy scaling and erythematous patches on areas of the skin that are rich in sebaceous glands are characteristic of seborrheic dermatitis, a chronic inflammatory skin condition. Although this condition is seen commonly in healthy adults, it is more common and more severe in patients with HIV infection, particularly those with low CD4-cell counts. The condition often improves with antiretroviral therapy.

HIV testing is important in all persistent or atypical cases of seborrheic dermatitis.

Treatment of seborrheic dermatitis includes topical antifungal agents, topical glucocorticoids, and selenium sulfide shampoos.

Key learning point: The widespread presence of erythema and yellowish scaling of skin areas that are rich in sebaceous glands, consistent with seborrheic dermatitis, should prompt testing for HIV infection.

B) INCORRECT:

This test is not warranted because seborrheic dermatitis is not typically associated with sarcoidosis.

C) INCORRECT:

This test is not warranted because seborrheic dermatitis is not typically associated with syphilis.

D) INCORRECT:

This test is not warranted because seborrheic dermatitis is not typically associated with tuberculosis.

E) INCORRECT:

This test is not warranted because seborrheic dermatitis is not typically associated with enteric parasitic infections.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with an itchy, scaly rash involving her eyebrows, nose, and ears. The rash first appeared 6 weeks ago and has continued to worsen. The patient also reports intermittent flaking on her scalp for the past 5 years. Physical examination reveals pink patches with scale involving her eyebrows, nasolabial folds, and retroauricular areas (figure).
Which one of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Terbinafine daily by mouth for 6 weeks
Narrowband ultraviolet light therapy three times weekly

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antifungal agents such as terbinafine have shown limited efficacy and are not recommended for seborrheic dermatitis, given the chronicity of the condition and risks of the medication.

B) INCORRECT:

Clobetasol cream is a highly potent topical glucocorticoid that should not be used on the face because of risks for skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and hypertrichosis. A lower-potency glucocorticoid, such as 1 or 2.5% hydrocortisone cream, is a better alternative for short-term use.

C) INCORRECT:

Moisturizing cream is helpful for xerosis and overall skin health, but it is minimally effective for seborrheic dermatitis. Emollients primarily help diminish the amount of scale or flaking but do not alter the etiology or course of the condition.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with seborrheic dermatitis (dandruff), a chronic, relapsing inflammatory dermatitis that affects the scalp, face, and occasionally the chest and intertriginous areas. Topical antifungal agents are the mainstay of treatment. Ketoconazole, ciclopirox olamine, and sulfur-based formulations are first-line agents for the face and scalp. Seborrheic dermatitis is caused in part by a reaction to fungi (Malassezia; formerly known as Pityrosporum) that reside naturally in hair follicles of the scalp, face, chest, and back, thus the rationale for antifungal agents. The same organism also causes tinea versicolor, which is treated similarly to seborrheic dermatitis.

Topical glucocorticosteroids can be used for the pruritus and erythema of seborrheic dermatitis, and those of low potency are often used in combination with topical antifungal agents to enhance efficacy. During the initial phase of treatment, when inflammation is at its worst, 1% or 2.5% hydrocortisone cream may be combined with a topical antifungal. Once the dermatitis is controlled, the topical glucocorticoid is stopped to avoid long-term use, and maintenance therapy consists of topical antifungal therapy alone.

Key learning point: Appropriate therapy for facial seborrheic dermatitis consists of topical antifungal agents (ketoconazole, ciclopirox olamine, or sulfur-based creams or shampoo).

E) INCORRECT:

Narrow-band ultraviolet therapy is an effective therapy for psoriasis and other dermatoses but would be inappropriate for the treatment of seborrheic dermatitis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office with a 3-month history of an itchy rash on his face. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with early-onset Parkinson disease. His only medication is pramipexole. Physical examination shows the findings seen in the photograph. There is copious dandruff on his scalp without underlying erythema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's pruritic rash affecting areas of high sebaceous activity (i.e., face, eyelids, scalp) is typical of seborrheic dermatitis. While most cases are idiopathic, there is an increased prevalence of seborrheic dermatitis in patients with HIV infection, underlying neurological conditions (e.g. Parkinson disease, stroke), and intestinal malabsorption syndromes (e.g., celiac sprue). Malassezia furfur and Malassezia globosa are yeasts that are thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of seborrheic dermatitis, but the exact mechanism is unknown. Scalp lesions are typically treated with antifungal shampoos, and facial lesions are treated with low-dose topical steroids and/or antifungal creams.

B) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (eczema) can manifest with a pruritic, scaling rash involving the scalp and face, as is seen in this patient. However, atopic dermatitis typically manifests first in childhood, often with lesions on the face in infancy and lesions on the flexural surfaces of the body in childhood and adolescence. Moreover, it is commonly associated with other atopic diseases such as asthma and allergic rhinitis, neither of which this patient has.
Image Description:

Nodules and papular vesicles with crusting, scaling, and impetigo are seen on the head of an infant

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis (DM) is characterized by myopathy, which is commonly preceded by cutaneous features such as midfacial erythema that affects the nasolabial folds, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, cutaneous manifestations of DM are typically nonpruritic and involve the eyelids, unlike what is seen here. Moreover, DM is commonly associated with Gottron papules and the Shawl sign, neither of which is seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Scaly, erythematous papules and periungual erythema are visible on the dorsal aspect of the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints.

Both localization and appearance are typical of Gottron papules, which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) typically manifests with symmetric erythema over the bridge of the nose and cheeks, and characteristically spares the nasolabial folds (butterfly rash). This patient's rash involves the nasolabial folds as well as the scalp and is more prominent around the beard. In addition, other early manifestations of SLE, such as constitutional (e.g., fatigue, myalgia, fever), mucocutaneous (e.g., oral ulcers), and musculoskeletal (e.g., arthritis, arthralgia) symptoms are absent.
Image Description:

An erythematous macular rash with adherent keratotic scaling is visible over the nasal bridge, cheek (malar eminence), brow, and chin. The rash has spared the nasolabial fold. Mild cheilitis is also visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of the malar rash typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus. Because this rash typically affects both malar eminences symmetrically, resembling butterfly wings, it is also referred to as a "butterfly rash."

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic/recurrent central facial erythema (nose and medial cheeks), as seen in this patient, is a common feature of rosacea. However, the lesions of rosacea are not pruritic, and the characteristic signs of rosacea, such as telangiectasia and/or papules and pustules in the affected area, are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Papules, pustules, and erythema can be seen on the forehead, nose, and cheeks. A coarse, erythematous, and enlarged bulbous nose (rhinophyma) is also visible.
questions.hint: This is a benign condition with a biphasic age of onset that most commonly manifests with scales on the scalp in infancy (cradle cap) or on the face in adolescence or early adulthood.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of a recurrent, itchy rash on his face and scalp. He mentions that he has been using a new shaving cream once a week for the past 5 months. He was diagnosed with HIV a year ago and is currently on triple antiretroviral therapy. He reports drinking several six-packs of beer each week. Vital signs are normal. A photograph of the rash is provided. A similar rash is present near the hairline of the scalp, and greasy yellow scales are noted at the eyelid margins. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) can manifest with a pruritic, erythematous rash. However, this patient's rash is not limited to the parts of the skin he uses the shaving cream on; the scaly rash is also seen on his eyelids and forehead, and scales in ACD are dry and white rather than greasy and yellow. Moreover, ACD develops within 48 hours of contact with the allergen, and the 2-month period between this patient changing shaving cream and developing a rash is not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic lesions can manifest as pruritic erythematous scaly plaques that are recurrent with symptom-free intervals. However, the typical lesions will be sharply-demarcated with numerous silvery-white scales and have a predilection to occur on the scalp, back, and extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees. The characteristic silvery scales of a psoriatic lesion may be rubbed off while bathing or minimized with the use of lotions, making differentiating between psoriasis and this patient's condition difficult. It is helpful to consider nail changes, arthritis, and a family history of psoriasis if the lesions are indeterminate.

C) CORRECT:

Seborrheic dermatitis is an idiopathic, chronic, relapsing condition that manifests with a pruritic rash, affecting the face, eyelids, and/or scalp. Predisposing factors include immunodeficiency (e.g., HIV infection) and Parkinson disease. Malassezia furfur and Malassezia globosa are thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of seborrheic dermatitis, but the exact mechanism is unknown. Treatment consists of topical antifungals (e.g., ketoconazole) and topical steroids (for moderate to severe disease).

Key learning point: Seborrheic dermatitis presents as a pruritic, erythematous rash with greasy yellow scales on the face and scalp, and is more common in individuals with HIV.

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic/recurrent central facial erythema (nose and medial cheeks) is a common feature of rosacea. In some patients, the eyelids are also involved (i.e., blepharitis in ocular rosacea). However, the lesions of rosacea are not pruritic and scales, if present, are dry and white, unlike in this patient. In addition, the most characteristic signs of rosacea, such as telangiectasia and/or papules and pustules in the affected area, are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis versicolor manifests with multiple, pruritic, well-demarcated lesions that may be mildly erythematous, hyperpigmented, or hypopigmented and are typically seen on the trunk and shoulders; the face is an uncommon site for pityriasis versicolor. The lesions have very fine white scales and do not tan, which is why they become more apparent after sun exposure.
questions.hint: This photograph shows well-defined erythematous plaques with fine, greasy yellow scales over the nasolabial folds. This condition can also affect infants and is known as cradle cap.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of an itchy rash on his face. He was diagnosed with early-onset Parkinson disease 6 months ago. His only medication is pramipexole. On examination, the findings are shown in the photograph. There is copious dandruff on his scalp without underlying erythema. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (eczema) can manifest with a pruritic, scaling rash involving the scalp and face, as is seen in this patient. However, atopic dermatitis typically manifests first in childhood, often with lesions on the face in infancy and lesions on the flexural surfaces of the body in childhood and adolescence. Moreover, it is commonly associated with other atopic diseases such as asthma and allergic rhinitis, neither of which this patient has.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermatomyositis (DM) is characterized by myopathy, which is commonly preceded by cutaneous features such as midfacial erythema that affects the nasolabial folds, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, cutaneous manifestations of DM are typically nonpruritic and involve the eyelids, unlike what is seen here. Moreover, DM is commonly associated with Gottron papules and the Shawl sign, neither of which is seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) typically manifests with symmetric erythema over the bridge of the nose and cheeks, and characteristically spares the nasolabial folds (butterfly rash). This patient's rash involves the nasolabial folds as well as the scalp and is more prominent around the beard. In addition, other early manifestations of SLE, such as constitutional (e.g., fatigue, myalgia, fever), mucocutaneous (e.g., oral ulcers), and musculoskeletal (e.g., arthritis, arthralgia) symptoms are absent.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's pruritic rash affecting areas of high sebaceous activity (i.e., face, eyelids, scalp) is typical of seborrheic dermatitis. While most cases are idiopathic, there is an increased prevalence of seborrheic dermatitis in patients with HIV infection, underlying neurological conditions (e.g. Parkinson disease, stroke), and intestinal malabsorption syndromes (e.g., celiac sprue). Malassezia furfur and Malassezia globosa are yeasts that are thought to play a role in the pathogenesis of seborrheic dermatitis, but the exact mechanism is unknown. Scalp lesions are typically treated with antifungal shampoos, and facial lesions are treated with low-dose topical steroids and/or antifungal creams.

Key learning point: Seborrheic dermatitis presents as a pruritic, scaly rash in areas of high sebaceous activity and is more common in patients with neurological conditions like Parkinson disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic/recurrent central facial erythema (nose and medial cheeks), as seen in this patient, is a common feature of rosacea. However, the lesions of rosacea are not pruritic, and the characteristic signs of rosacea, such as telangiectasia and/or papules and pustules in the affected area, are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This is a benign condition with a biphasic age of onset that most commonly manifests with scales on the scalp in infancy (cradle cap) or on the face in adolescence or early adulthood.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of worsening facial rash that has not improved with over-the-counter moisturizers. He reports moderate itching and burning. Physical examination findings are shown. The patient works in a high-stress environment and has been sleeping poorly. What is the most appropriate initial management approach?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic antifungals are reserved for refractory seborrheic dermatitis that has not responded to topical treatments. Initial management involves topical therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has localized seborrheic dermatitis. Topical antifungals are first-line therapy for all patients with seborrheic dermatitis. For moderate to severe disease, a short course of topical corticosteroids (e.g., up to 4 weeks) may be considered in addition to antifungals.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids may be considered as adjunctive therapy for moderate to severe seborrheic dermatitis, but they are not the first-line treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical metronidazole is used to treat rosacea, which can manifest with facial erythema and may be confused with seborrheic dermatitis. However, seborrheic dermatitis is characterized by scaling and involves sebaceous-rich areas, while rosacea typically manifests with papules, pustules, and telangiectasias without scaling.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcineurin inhibitors like tacrolimus are used for refractory seborrheic dermatitis that has not responded to first-line treatment. They are not appropriate initial therapy.
